title: Data Storytelling - Operationalized for your Data Story
text:
Data Literacy
Definition: The ability to understand and communicate data.

Data has no value for data illiterate people!
People can be data literate with knowing much statistics or even programming!
As data scientists we are expected to

know some statistics and programming
communicate data insights on a high level to data literate people
being able to communicate data insights to less data illiterate people



The challenges for your project: 

Bring you main insights across to an audience with low and intermediate data literacy!

3 Essential Elements of Data Stories
Data, Visuals, Narrative


The three essential elements of data stories.



Explain. Narrative coupled with data.

What‚Äôs happening in the data?
What is the context?
Guide through the data structure!
Why is a particular insight important?

Enlighten. Visuals applied to data.

Some insights are hard with numbers only.
Show patterns and outliers otherwise hidden.

Engage. Narrative and visuals merged together.

Engage (or even entertain) an audience.
Visuals capture interest, only a story holds attention.

title: Visual Communication and Data Story-telling
text:
7 Examination and Assessment
From the Handbook:
Assessment Type: Project Report (6000 - 8000 words)
This is the official word count from the handbook. However, the instructor will not count words and will not assess the report based on fulfilling the word count. Essential parts the submissions will be visual anyway.
Details about the project report: The project report is a website which tells a data story which is rendered with quarto.
It includes

a slide deck used to tell the story in a presentation,
a written report tells the story for readers and gives more details and more visuals, e.g.¬†in Appendices.

Optional the submission can also include a dashboard with interactive graphs which enables individual exploration by the reader.
The report must be reproducible. That means the source code must be provided.
However, the report must be readable without reading code. The target audience is not a programmer and they should not see code while reading. Technical parts should be in the appendix. 
Delivery via GitHub.






Important



You can make your data story into a nice thing to show your competence to the outside world. It is not too difficult to publish the report as a website from your final repository. Make your report such that it is worth to publish and show it!

text:
10 Artifical Intelligence (AI) Use Policy
This policy covers any generative AI tool, such as ChatGPT, Elicit, etc. This includes text, code, slides, artwork/graphics/video/audio and other products.
We instructors encouraged to using and exploring AI tools for these purposes:

Learning by dialog with a chatbot. AI chatbots can be very helpful to explain you concepts on your desired level and get a feeling about how certain topics are treated. You can ask for an easier or more detailed explanation or focus on certain aspects. Note: The capabilities are limited and you likely receive a lot of false information! An AI chat can be a good entry point to learn about a specific topic but the more specific it gets the more likely it is that AI will start to deliver useless or wrong answers. Using chatbots should remain a small part of your learning process. Rule of thumb: Spend not more than 25% of the learning time with chatting. There is no way around reading textbooks, reading software documentation, learning and understanding concepts, searching for help online, asking instructors or fellow students.
Have code snippets written. Tools like GitHub Copilot can be a great help in coding! You are encouraged to have them available and try them. The GitHub Copilot is free to use for students and teachers who joined GitHub Education), they can be integrated in your programming IDE like RStudio and VSCode. Copilots can speed up writing. However, they may deliver bad code. There is no way around understanding yourself what code is doing! Do not spend endless hours asking for new code with new prompts, spend time understanding a language and the functions and objects you are using! AI chatbots and Copilots can also help you to understand code. Copilots can be a great help to get a skeleton of code and an idea how your solution might look, they rarely deliver the complete code, expect that the code does not work, expect that the code seems to works but the results are wrong. You are 100% accountable for the code you produce, with or without the help of a copilot!
Have a draft text snippet written. Formulating and describing research questions, describing data, documenting code, interpreting results, and deriving conclusion from the results is an essential part of data science not direclty related to coding but verbal text. Chatbots are good in writing text which often appears as well readable. You can use this to inspire you and to polish and improve your texts. However, you are 100% accountable for the text you deliver. You are expected to know what your text is about and to be able to answer questions about what your text means! With text generated purely by chatbots, it is oftenn evident for us that students do not understand. We consider such cases worse than incomplete but sensible self-written text. Text written by chatbots is often very generic and not specific. In general, we value more specific text higher than generic text. Large parts of very generic text is considered worse than a shorter more specific text.
Note: Philosophical and legal questions around the training and use of chatbots and code copilots are controversially contested and re-examined constantly! We encourage to engage with such questions and become aware of arguments and debates.

If any part of this AI policy is confusing or uncertain, please reach out to us for a conversation before submitting your work.

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Data
In September 2019, YouGov survey asked 1,639 adults in the UK the following question:

In hindsight, do you think Britain was right/wrong to vote to leave EU?
üî≤ Right to leave | üî≤ Wrong to leave | üî≤ Don‚Äôt know

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Order Matters
Alphabetical order is rarely what you want!

PlotCode













ggplot(brexit, aes(x = opinion)) +
  geom_bar()

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Order Matters
Often good: Order by frequency

PlotCode













fct_infreq: (Creates and) reorders a factor by the frequency.
ggplot(brexit, aes(x = fct_infreq(opinion))) +
  geom_bar()

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Clean up labels

PlotCode













ggplot(brexit, aes(x = fct_infreq(opinion))) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(
    x = "Opinion",
    y = "Count"
  )

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Order Matters
Alphabetical order is rarely what you want!

PlotCode

  geom_bar()

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Use inherent level order
Reorder manually with a custom order

RelevelPlot


fct_relevel: Reorders the levels of a factor as specified

brexit <- brexit |> 
  mutate(region = fct_relevel(
    region,
    "london", "rest_of_south", "midlands_wales", "north", "scot"
  ))

title: Tips for Great Visualizations
text:
Clean factor labels
Reorder manually with a custom order

RecodePlot


fct_recode: Change factor levels by hand

brexit <- brexit |> 
  mutate(
    region = fct_recode(
      region,
      London = "london",
      `Rest of South` = "rest_of_south",
      `Midlands / Wales` = "midlands_wales",
      North = "north",
      Scotland = "scot"
    )
  )

title: Data Storytelling - Storyboarding Activity Guide
text:
Data, Visuals, Narrative


The three essential elements of data stories.

Storyboading is about a narrative and how it relates to data and visuals.


Explain. Narrative coupled with data.

What‚Äôs happening in the data?
What is the context?
Guide through the data structure!
Why is a particular insight important?

Enlighten. Visuals applied to data.

Some insights are hard with numbers only.
Show patterns and outliers otherwise hidden.

Engage. Narrative and visuals merged together.

Engage (or even entertain) an audience.
Visuals capture interest, only a story holds attention.

text:
Storyboarding

Definition: A story is an account of causally related or connected series of events.
A narrative always has a one-dimensional linear sequence, but we can decide

what is in and
in which order.

Storyboarding is a technique from the movie industry (invented at Disney‚Äôs in the 30‚Äôs, now part of pre-visualization) which can also be used for data presentations.
Main purpose: Build the story, not the exact visualizations (rough ideas are enough)!

Activity: Make a story board for your presentation. Follow the steps on the next slides.

title: Data Storytelling - Storyboarding Activity Guide
text:
Phase A: Story points!
Activity

Write down story points and/or brief visual sketches on sticky notes or cards.

There is no limit on the initial number of story-point card to generate!
Select the best 6 to 10 ones
Keep all, maybe you want to replace one
You can always create or refine one later

Already now you can play with your story points to search for a compelling story.


Arrange them in order
Replace, combine, refine, and reshuffle them
Use them to tell the story
Scrutinize and iterate your story

title: Data Storytelling - Storyboarding Activity Guide

Activity: Realize these steps in your storyboard.

Step 1: Identify your ‚ÄúAha‚Äù moment (main insight)
Step 2: Find your beginning (the setting and the ‚Äúhook‚Äù)
Step 3: Select your rising insights (narrative from the hook to the Aha moment)
Step 4: Conclude with solutions, next steps, empowerment to action, ‚Ä¶

When your storyboard is fixed

write the titles down in your slide deck and
start working on your final visuals such that they best support your story.

title: Quarto Hints
text:
1 Reading the quarto Documentation
You find almost everything in the quarto documentation Guide and the quarto documentation Reference. However, it is sometimes not so easy to find the right section to read for what problems.

Read the Guide to understand subtopics of quarto holistically. For example:

Authoring with topics like Markdown Basics, how to embed images, make tables and other interesting sections to check out. The subsection Scholarly Writing is important for

making an advanced front matter with more than title and author
how to work with citations (when you refer to references like articles in the text) and references (which appear at the end of the text)
how to make cross-references, e.g.¬†links from your text to numbers figures with captions and links to other sections

Computations explaining how to work with python and R code blocks
Tools for problems helping you to work within RStudio or VSCode
Documents for things related to the documents you want to render like your HTML-pages for project reports
Presentations for making presentations, in particular using the revealjs framework
More advanced sections about making dashboards, or websites, books, and manuscripts, or other so called projects (which are multi-document directories, e.g.¬†as stored in a GitHub repository)

Go to the Reference if you need a particular option or customization for your document or code chunk. For example:

What options are availbale to customize your HTML output or your revealjs Presentation
What options are available to customize the size of figures created by code blocks. This is in the section Code Cells.
Important: look into Knitr (default) if you work from RStudio mainly in R, select Jupyter if you render from a Jupyter notebook
What options are available about showing, fold or hide your code or other code execution output like warnings and message
Important: look into Knitr (default) if you work from RStudio mainly in R, select Jupyter if you render from a Jupyter notebook

title: Quarto Hints
text:
2 Citation, References, Literature Management
See above how to find guides in quarto on these topics. Additionally, it makes sense to think more about tools helping you to start a sustainable workflow for reading, archiving and citing scientific literature, for your future studies also beyond this course and beyond your studies going further in academia or industry jobs.

Find a literature manager! A recommendation is zotero (free to use). You can use it to

Collect literature you find browsing the internet or other literature. There are easy ways in zotero to import by just pasting in a DOI, are there a browser plugins that give you a button in your browser you can click when on the website of an article.
Read and annotate articles. Zotero can easily also archive PDFs of articles on your local machine and a PDF viewer. You can also annotate PDF there and there are other tools to access such annotations automatically.
Organize your literature into collections of topics of interest. (Any item can be in more collections!)
Export bibtex bibliographies (.bib-files) which you can use to embed them in your reports as references.bib to cite from

Learn how to work with references and citations in quarto! You do not need a full workflow on it you can also start small for just one project. It will pay off to get into this!
Search for video tutorials on literature management. Be aware that there are several options, but many are connected through free standards like bibtex or csl.

title: Quarto Hints
section: 3 From a quick report to a beautiful web article
text:
3 From a quick report to a beautiful web article
Quick report: A report produced fast for internal use for yourself or a few colleagues or outsiders you need to quickly share results with. Quick reports often have:

just title and author, no sophisticated front matter with date, affiliation, contact information, funding information, ‚Ä¶
code based figures just in place without captions and not being cross-referenced
code echo and code output (like warnings) appearing directly in the text, not nicely folded or removed/suppressed (after careful checks)

Web article: A well crafted report which is prepared to be readable by any outsider, e.g.¬†as a web site published from GitHub pages. For a beautiful web article you:

Have a sensible structure for Headers (#, ##, ###) which may also provide a sensible table of content (see toc related options for HTML)
Fold in Code (code-fold: true), and suppress any warnings (e.g., warnings: false) or other messages (e.g., messages: false) which are not relevant for the reader. If there was something relevant for the reader (like removed data points or whatever), write about it in your text.
Have well adjusted code-based figures. No cut-off labels. Large enough labels. Appropriate size (adjust fig-width and/or fig-height in quarto).
Do not show data frames as raw console out put but use a formatted table output. In R, use for example knitr::kable() (simple option) or advance table produced witht the gt package.
Use inline code to show numbers from your analysis in the text!
If not very brief introduce Figures and Table by making them referable see sections on cross-referencing. By doing that Figures and Tables also get a caption.
Cite sources you use for your report by using Links, Citations, and a final References sections (read the docs on this)

title: Quarto Hints
text:
4 Publish your project from GitHub
The quarto docs provide details and different ways to publish your report. Check the check the Publishing section in the quarto Guide.
As you are working from GitHub anyway, look at the section about publishing using GitHub Pages. There are three ways: (1) render to docs, (2) use the quarto publish command, (3) use GitHub actions. All are fine and documented. Just follow the steps when you do it the first time. The different ways are different. (1) has lowest ‚Äúoverhead‚Äù using other tools but requires more systematic manual work when updating a lot of files, it is great for one file reports which you do not need to update a lot. (2) is better if you need to update more often like in a website. (3) is the most advanced using GitHub actions provided bny GitHub.

These are two different formats for data storytelling. However, the markdown structure has some similarity:

Defines a Subsection and its header
Define a Slide and its header



So, a common workflow Presentation to Report or Report to Presention can be to copy the file and then adjust the format in the YAML and adjust the structure. Typically:

Shorten text, e.g.¬†to list for presentation, make text paragraphs from text lists
Refine the headers (#, ##, ‚Ä¶) for the purpose
Check if visuals work well in the new format

title: Student Topics
text:
Important



Schedule for student topics and pitches updated: https://github.com/JU-F22-MDSSB-MET-03/Schedule-Organization



1 To do
The presentation of a data visualization topic is an expected student contribution.
Presentations should take place from Week 5 (Oct 4) to 7 (Oct 18).
Presentations should be done in teams of two (exceptionally also three).

To do until Sep, 26:

Select a topic you want to work out from the list below and two alternatives.
Write your topical priorities on Teams in the course‚Äôs general channel as a reply to the respective conversation (from Tuesday Sep, 20 ‚ÄúDataViz Topic Distribution‚Äù).
Reply as existing team or individually and we will form teams then.
Be prepared to be assigned to a presentation date in one of the three weeks 5, 6, or 7. Add any restriction you have in the reply on Teams.




2 Topics


Visualization and comparison of distributions of numerical variables (Boxplots, Violin Plots, Histograms, Density plots, Ridgeline plots) (Inspiration from the stories https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/OneNum.html, https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/OneNumOneCatSeveralObs.html, and https://www.data-to-viz.com/caveat/boxplot.html)
Visualization of one categorical variable or nested categorical variables (Barplots and Lollipops and versions of stacking and dodging, Pie charts, Treemaps, Word Clouds) (Inspiration from the stories https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/OneNumOneCat.html, https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/SevCatOneNumNestedOneObsPerGroup.html, https://www.data-to-viz.com/caveat/multi_distribution.html, and https://www.data-to-viz.com/caveat/pie.html)
Visualization of two or three numerical variables (Scatter plots, Scatter plots with summary statistics - regression or loess, the overplotting problem, density and contour plots, What can be used for the thrid variable ‚Äì size, color, ‚Ä¶?) (Inspiration from the stories https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/TwoNum.html and https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/ThreeNum.html)
Two numerical variables where one is ordered (e.g.¬†time) and an additional categorical one (Line plots, Area plots, Focusing, the Spaghetti plot problem) (Inspiration from the stories https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/TwoNumOrdered.html, https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/OneCatSevOrderedNum.html, and https://www.data-to-viz.com/caveat/spaghetti.html)

Optional topics:

Dendro grams (Hierarchical Clustering)
Networks (Inspiration from https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/AdjacencyMatrix.html)
Maps (Inspiration from https://www.data-to-viz.com/graph/choropleth.html, https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/GPSCoordWithoutValue.html, and https://www.data-to-viz.com/story/GPSCoordWithValue.html)
Interactive graphs (plotly, shiny, or observable)
Tableau and Power BI


Generally, for all specific visualization there is more information on https://datavizcatalogue.com and https://www.data-to-viz.com.


3 Structure and Format
Structure of the student presentation:

Explain the underlying visualization task
Provide examples of solutions using different data sources
Compare different solutions with the same data
Finish with a summary about good and bad uses for the visualization type, common problems, do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts

Format:

Provide a ‚Äúhands-on‚Äù document where code and data is provided which produce visualizations. It can be a markdown or notebook file in which you mix text and code or a raw script where you put some descriptive text in comments. It can be in R or python. (If you want to use something else please coordinate before.) A repository in the organization https://github.com/JU-F22-MDSSB-MET-03 can be provided for distribution to others. Contact me on Teams. Students will then be enabled to clone it and play with the code.
You do not need presentation slides but you can. You can use revealjs in quarto to nicely present code and visualizations.
